comments.commentBody:
James Heckman's data show that learning deficiencies begin prior to 3 years old. What happens BEFORE kindergarten determines how a child will fare in the k-12 years. READ: The parents, the parents, the parents - the family, the home, and the childcare environment from birth to 5 y.o. is the key.

Learning gaps are not created by public schools. Achievement deficiencies are simply detected in k-12 grades, because that's when/where the kids are tested - and only then are they compared to the rest of the world. Blaming teachers = killing the messenger ... it's a lame excuse, and an expensive mistake.

It's the parents - it's the American village - that has failed. If we want to compete with the rest of the world, then American parents, extended family, friends, childcare workers, coaches, mentors, clergy, neighbors, and businessmen will need to help participate in the education of children. Most cannot be bothered, because it's not in their job descriptions. But that's how other cultures view & value education, and that's why they beat us on achievement tests.

http://maplewood-brentwood.patch.com/articles/blaming-teachers-for-poor-...

The only think that will save the GOP is to finally Annex Canada and Mexico. We need the leadership of Governor Perry to bring this bright day closer! Can't you New Yorkers see the socialist terror squatting across your northern border?
Finally the middle class recognized that the Republican party serves only the wealthy. Ryan's plan is brazen right wing engineering and it's high time to discard it into the rubbish bin.

"gee grandma, what big teeth you have..."

from the classic fairy tale, "little red (paul) ryan hood".

Don't forget on the heels of the Ryan Budget vote (wasn't even a bill was it?), the Senate rejected the proposal to stop funneling taxpayer money to oil companies. So, the message is clear: we'll go broke if we pay for the healthcare of the soon-to-be elderly who have paid into the system for 40 years, but we've still got billions to give to oil companies while we're all paying $4 a gallon.  Even if we give some of them the benefit of the doubt that they think these votes are really in the country's best interests, how could they not see how these votes would be perceived?  I'd never contacted my Congressman, but this Medicare fiasco resulted in my sending him a few emails.  I told him I want it there when I reach 65 and if it's going broke then let's try Medicare for all like every other rational country, stop drinking the "private sector solutions" Kool-Aid and move on!  Why would anyone making under a million dollars a year ever vote for the GOP?
It would seem as though the Tea Party candidate's run also contributed to the loss taking 8% of conservative voters away from the Republican candidate.

LOL I'm a liberal Democrat in the vaunted New York 26th. LOL What a night!!
Two wars, decreased taxes on the rich, an unpaid for prescription plan, unregulated banking by brokerage houses and ridiculous spending by the Republicans for eight years has the country in a massive hole. So the elephants want to shaft the populace at the end of their working careers to help right the ship. Tonight was just the beginning of a long overdue payback. Lace up your boots. the Republicans are going to be taken for a final ride.
Single payer health care for ALL.

The 1967 borders have already failed.  Those borders previously enticed the Arabs into starting a war.  They lost.  As Bibi said, everyone knows that there will be a new state for Arabs called Palestine, and the question to be addressed is whether there will be a Jewish state.  That was the single most important line of Bibi's speech.  By way of contrast, you seem to think that Jews should be content with Jewish neighborhoods.  That was tried in Europe.  It failed, horribly.  Bibi's plan has not been tried.  You seem to be the one who is resistant to new ideas.

I was on a flight when an attendant asked if there was a doctor on board. I said that I was a pediatrician and she that was just fine. The patient was a middle-aged man with chest pain. Another physician responded to the call.

I said to the other doctor, “Why don’t you take this one since I’m a pediatrician?”

He responded, “You’re closer to this case than me. I’m a retired pathologist.”

So the two of us worked together and stabilized him during the flight. An ambulance was waiting on arrival.

Another flight. Another chest pain. This time it was an elderly woman flying by herself. I was the only physician on flight. Again, I did my best to treat her. A ground control team asked me if I thought they should divert the plane. Her vital signs were abnormal but I thought she would make it to the landing. An ambulance awaited her also.

Another time a man who was vomiting uncontrollably. Another doctor responded and I was not chosen. I was thinking to myself. “This patient is right up my alley. I make my living off vomiting and they didn’t pick me – oh, well.”

Shirley Press, MD

As usual, this subject brings out passionate reactions, with the expected condescending and insulting remarks directed at women who choose home birth. But there are some thoughtful and sensible comments. Especially encouraging are the ones from doctors and med students who support the idea of home birth with reasonable precautions. As several people note, the bottom line is a healthy mother and baby.

I never cease to be stunned by the vitriol and animosity of some. RocDoc (#111), I am not a ‘homebirther’, I am an educated, conscientious person who made a considered, cautious and informed decision (see comment #59). Your friends are boring you with their enthusiastic home birth stories? With your simmering hostility, I am amazed you even have any friends like that. Just jettison those crunchy losers and stick with your clever and enlightened hospital birther friends. It will be better for your blood pressure to only be surrounded by people who ‘have a baby, go home and deal.’ And, I suppose, who also don’t tell you about it. Especially if they are attempting to spread joy and light. KidsDoc (#114), another one using the pejorative “homebirther”. You don’t accept us in your practice? Why would anyone want to go to an inflexible, supercilious pediatrician in the first place? No thanks indeed.

When I had my babies at home, I wasn’t looking for a ‘magical experience’. I didn’t chant or make placenta burgers, although who cares if someone does? I did want to plant the placenta with a tree in honor of the new baby, but it was winter. Put the placenta in the freezer, I suggested? My late husband was appalled and replied through his gagging, “There is no way from now until spring I am going to look at that placenta every time I get an ice cube.” That was the extent of any New Age organic movement for me. What I wanted was safety and, for me, home birth was the safest choice I could offer my baby.

Since you'll never mention it in your writing, I will include here the surprising reality of how much better an Arab Muslim's life is while living in Israel than in any other country in the entire Muslim world.

On what planet was this peaceful Egyptian revolution? I know it's fashionable in the US to contrast the "peaceful" Egyptians with those savage Palestinians, but in fact the Egyptians engaged in street battles with the police and while the government was the one that committed most of the lethal violence, street battles aren't, you know, nonviolent.

Some Palestinians have been trying nonviolence for years. They get arrested or beaten or shot. Emily Henochowicz, an American college student (and Jewish, by the way) lost her eye last year when an Israeli shot a tear gas canister which hit her in the face. I hope the Palestinians employ nonviolence on an increasingly large scale, but they don't need Mr. Friedman's typically patronizing advice, which as usual blames the Palestinians for not winning over the Israelis.

I also hope the Palestinians go to the UN and obtain recognition. It might open doors to legal pressure that could then be placed on Israel. Waiting for the US to do the right thing and be an evenhanded mediator is a waste of time.

Really excellent piece; and really excellent advice. It doesn't matter so much that Netanyahu may be laughing at what he might characterize as naiveté: what you suggest is simple, effective, and could be supported by the whole world outside of Israel and non-Israeli Palestine.

But the questions you pose are trenchant. It doesn't matter that the whole world thinks the suggestion brilliant. It matters what the leaders of the two major protagonists can do without getting themselves shot ... by their own people.

We remain in the housing doldrums significantly because banks have onerous lending requirements. Believe it or not, 20% down low doc loans did NOT get us into this mess. Making 100% down loans on inflated values to uncreditworthy buyers did. This was greed oriented. Instead they sit on cash and loan it back to the govt increasing their capital reserves. They should have been compelled to make housing loans instead of swinging the pendulum too far in the other direction.

The 20% down loans to credit worthy buyers have been around for years and appealed to self employed, newly employed, immigrants, investors, people willing to put their money where their mouths are. Particularly now with deflated values.

Bringing back these loans will help clear out unsold inventory overhanging the market. Currently, this pool of buyers are prohibited from the market when they could pull us out faster. Now, only cash buyers can buy these properties. Waiting for full documented buyers is like hen's teeth. And we're dying until they grow.

http://www.thenoflieszone.com/2011/04/its-about-jobs.html

When are the smart people going to come out and say....

Housing is not a sustainable product in our economy anymore.

Invent something to sell and market around the world and get our country prosperous instead of buliding bulding and more building!

Wake up America - the party is over - stop the spin on economic housing to sustain our country. Its not working and wont work.

All government intervention does is punt the ball into the future, does not really solve anything.  The housing market has to be allowed to find a natural clearing price where the buyers can afford to own the home.  Only then will the housing market and the economy as a whole can start functioning normally.  It is not the end of the world if a person/family has to leave their house and live in an apartment they can afford.  I do that now, and i am happy!

The real music that nobody wants to hear is that we NEED the housing crash - and bad! HOW can the broader economy thrive when housing is STEALING as much as 50% of people's net income???
Yes - folks are going to need to actually WORK again now that their home is now longer "worth a million bucks". (yeah yeah, every piece of junk was supposed to be worth a million billion catrillion bucks).

But if everyone's house is supposed to be worth a million bucks, is ANYONE's house really worth a million bucks???

But yes, we do need protection for consumers that were pressed into absurd housing doubt in the rush by predatory lending institutions. Fine.

But really, let's put our feet back on the ground, get back to some real work and rebuild a real American economy.

"while prices, driven down by foreclosures, are plumbing new depths." Really? Have prices gone below the levels that existed before the recent 2006 peak? All that I have seen and read indicates that they are still above the levels of 2000 in many places. The continued need to artificially inflate housing prices is an addiction that needs breaking. Housing prices are not universally "at new depths". To having continued growth in housing costs is not a savings plan, nor an "asset". It is yet another fraudulent way of borrowing from future generations and placing the burden on them to pay yet higher and higher amounts.

We have no moral or financial obligation to buttress any investment. Responsible lending practices lead to stable values. Expectations of unrealistic returns lead to speculation and feed the gambler's addiction. Grow up people. Save for the future and buy within one's budget. It will be a painful transition for a society so dependent on buying first and paying later (or not paying at all).

And of course because it makes sense, because it is fair, because it would set standards devoid of loopholes, exception or exemption, because it actually focuses on long term stability over short term profit taking, the banks and special interests will fight it tooth and nail.
It can't be said often enough that, despite all the rhetoric and attempts to shift blame to the consumer alone, it was the 'experts' who made the final calls on who to sell homes to in the first place-who actively worked to put anybody with a pulse into their own place(and pocket a nice chunk of change each time they did). And it was the 'experts' that came out of this with huge profits from a no-strings-attached bailout when this all came crashing down-not the homeowners.It is those same 'experts' who are profitting even now. The homeowners? They are just desperately trying to hang on to the dream and the home they bought into in their naivety when they still had jobs and bright futures-before wealthy and powerful special interests found a way to turn that dream into a nightmare.
The plan is just what we need and so it is what we are least likely to see.

What is the use of a credit that has to be paid back in two years as the housing crisis still tanks away? And what is the use of 'let them rent' when renters don't take an active interest in where they live (if it don't work it's the landlords problem). New ownership is the key and that won't happen until prices come into line with incomes. Let the values tank so we, the common people, can afford.

As U.S. house prices fall, more homeowners are defaulting on mortgages even though they have the resources to maintain payments.
Strategic defaults will grow as more households see their properties decline in value below the amounts they owe.
This has led many homeowners to conclude they may be better off defaulting—even when they are financially able to keep up with their payments—and handing back the keys to their homes.
Such so-called strategic defaults are now common enough to jeopardize the already-weak housing and mortgage markets. If the trend continues, strategic defaults could both accelerate the pace of home foreclosures and also make it harder for new borrowers to obtain mortgages.
Check Patrick T. McHenry's Facebook page -- he is getting SLAMMED.

I thank Elizabeth Warren for standing up for fairness and working hard for the middle class American. At this point when so many Americans can hardly keep their heads above water, the Republicans are trying to scuttle the one voice constantly organizing protection for the common man. Doesn't anyone in Congress realize people have lost their lives as we knew it? Jobs and careers continue on a downward trend, homes and savings are lost, education is no longer a goal, families are split because greed took over businesses, and not only is college out of the question for most middle class families, an education is not the value it once proved to be. Representative Patrick McHenry please work to help us, not your party. I see that you have been in office since 2004 and there is little to show for it. You were there before the financial crisis and after, all you seem to offer is negativity..  Please reward Elizabeth Warren for her tireless effort to raise the standards in our country.
Patrick McHenry? That's the same guy who tried to defend Erik Prince during the Blackwater congressional hearings. I would say that being attacked by him is a sign that you're doing something right.
